so starting with a background on power
distribution planning the goal of this
process is to plan all the
infrastructure needed to deliver
electricity to end customers
so there's a number of different pieces
of equipment in this flow power will
start off at some sort of power
Generating Station it'll be stepped up
to a transmission voltage where it can
flow across large transmission lines
then as it gets closer to end customers
it'll go to an electrical substation
where it gets stepped down via
substation Transformers these will step
the power down to a distribution voltage
where it can flow across smaller
distribution lines and finally once it's
very closely End customer it'll go
through another Transformer or a step
down to the voltage of the End customer
needs and so all of the pieces all these
pieces of equipment need to be carefully
planned to ensure safety reliability and
affordability
every single piece of equipment here has
some sort of capacity where if and the
electricity at any point goes over that
capacity you'll get an overload which is
very bad not only will this cause
blackouts but this also can damage
expensive equipment or in the worst case
start fires in California we've had
quite a few large wildfires the result
of electrical equipment
recently this planning process has
become even more complicated because we
have all these exciting new technologies
like renewable energy like solar and
wind as well as electric vehicles and
Battery Technology which are all awesome
because they don't emit any carbon but
they're more challenging because they're
distributed and time varying so
like I said these are difficult to plan
because uh the the time series Behavior
varies uh on the for the hour of the day
or the day of the week or season of the

consumption of these Technologies so you
need to consider the full time series
when planning these out
and in these these Technologies are also

um
despite all that it's still really

these Technologies are quite slow uh
especially around electric vehicle

Kavala takes a new approach to all this
by doing bottom-up forecasting which
means we forecast
energy at the uh at the level of
individual electrical customers uh to
predict their time series energy
behavior and which technology they will
adopt this has multiple benefits but one
of the big benefits is that you can
account for more Geographic and building
specific input features
you can also more precisely model the
time varying behavior of these different
Energy Technologies
and you also uh

California's electric vehicles targets
could cost the state up to 50 billion

so now I'll talk about what our
forecasting pipeline actually looks like
so we'll take in a variety of different
types of inputs the first of which is
just general building characteristics
like whether it's a commercial or
residential the square footage tons of
other features like that we also will
take in the historical energy usage of
that building if we know it if not we'll
use a simulated version
and then we also use these top down
targets which are a really important
part of how utilities and Regulators
tend to plan because they're often
working with mandates that may have come
from other parts of the government and
their goal is to make sure that they're
going to be able to fit a certain amount
of either renewable energy or electric

and so uh from these inputs will predict
the the technologies that might be
adopted at specific buildings this can

energy and capacities or specific
electric vehicle
and will also predict the future energy
usage of each of those buildings and the
goal here is not to get 100 accuracy
because that's certainly not possible
but the goal is to create a
representative scenario that can be used
for planning purposes to identify
problem areas and do more detailed
Geographic analysis of what the impacts
are of these targets
there's a few big challenges in this
pipeline
the first
is uh that there's a lot of independent
interdependencies between the individual
tasks and predictions in this workflow
so the first type of interdependency is
temporal dependencies those are pretty
straightforward this just means that for
example if we're trying to determine the
behavior of some building in 2030 we
need to know whether we were predicting
that they would buy an electric vehicle
we also have dependencies between these
different Technologies for example if
someone buys an electric vehicle that'll
increase their overall energy usage and
then make them more likely to purchase a
residential solar system later on
and then because of these top-down
targets as mentioning earlier we also
have Geographic dependencies where we
can't just predict which Technologies
would be adopted at buildings with just
a simple yes or no we need to score
their likelihood and then weigh them
against all the other buildings in the
geographic area to make sure we're
meeting these top down targets we have
for each year
and the Second Challenge is the scale of
data time series data can get very big
especially when you have geospatial
components as well
so for us we're running these uh in the
largest forecasts we're running
predictions over millions of buildings
for each of these generating hourly time
series data per building over 10 or more
years and so this can end up being
trillions of data points or terabytes of
data
and so these scales data transfer can
become a major bottleneck so you really
need to pay attention to things like
um data locality and caching making sure
you have optimized storage and making
sure your read and write processes are
efficient
so Ray helps in a bunch of ways in
particular we leverage Ray actors to run
this workflow and that gives us a lot of
flexibility and scalability so some of
the big strengths of reactors are there
that that they're highly scalable you
can scale them up to thousands or even
tens of thousands or potentially
hundreds of thousands of workers
there are also very flexible since
they're basically like riding a normal
python class so you can write arbitrary

they also can communicate fast with each
other which is really important for the
different interdependencies we have
and then in addition since they're
staple you can
intelligently cache certain types of
data in in these actors that are
relevant for your workflow
so for this forecast workflow
specifically
we have two different types of actors
the first is a forecast manager this is
going to be what's managing the overall
job flow it'll also spawn a bunch of
child actors to do the actual work
and it'll also run some amount of
centralized computations ideally as
little as possible because we don't want
to be centrally bottlenecked but some of
these are pretty required for the
workflow
and then we'll also have these batch
forecaster actors
so each of these all these will do like
the bulk of actual work and they'll be
responsible for predicting behavior for
batches of buildings in the forecast and
they'll also be able to cache data
throughout the life cycle
to show how these actors work together
I'll walk through what one year of our
forecast workflow looks like
so we'll start off with the forecast
manager triggering the start of
forecasting a particular year
then we'll fan out to all the batch
forecaster actors in this case these
will predict the electric vehicle
adoption likelihood for all the
buildings they're responsible for
those predictions will all happen in
parallel once that's done these results
will then be returned back to the
forecast manager which is able to run a
central process to assign which
buildings actually adopt electric
vehicles in this scenario then that
information will be propagated back to
the batch forecasters
and then we'll move on to the next
technology in the workflow in this case
it's solar so we'll predict the solar
adoption likelihood in parallel then
once that's done we'll collect those
results back to the forecast manager
again then we can repeat the process for
any other Technologies in the workflow
so next we've got batteries there's also
a bunch of other Technologies not listed
here that might be relevant some of
these include
Energy Efficiency upgrades or building
electrification upgrades like heat pumps
as well as demand response programs
and the point of doing all these
sequentially is that we want to be able
to use the outputs from previous steps
as inputs into later steps because like
I was mentioning earlier these
Technologies all influence each other so
for example buying electric vehicle
means more likely to buy a solar system
because you have higher Energy savings
than all of that can influence whether
it actually makes sense for this
building to purchase a like battery
system because that really is going to
take all the different types of energy

and then as well there's also in all

eventually we'll have that final result
and then we'll be able to write that

that summary will be returned and the

we're forecasting
and eventually repeat it for any future

then this shows what the batch

that's relevant to those building that's

So eventually the forecast manager will

on each of these actors these will run

then like I said the rest of the

uh so when you're doing batch forecast
or batch processing there are a lot of
considerations that can be pretty
different from Real Time a Time series
usage and so what that ends up meaning
is that time series databases are not
very well suited for these batch
processing workflows
so instead it's much better to store all
your data in your Cloud Object Store
because this is going to be much more
scalable to whatever needs if you have
thousands of workers running in parallel
you're going to have trouble with all
those trying to read from a Time series
database so your Object Store is going
to be more scalable
and parquet files in particular end up
being a good choice because they
compress well
and they they any kind of data tools
you'll want to use are going to operate
well with them
but it's a challenge that you still have
is figuring out how to align your file
structure to all your usage patterns
uh so at Kavala we have a few different
usage patterns
one of these is retrieving data for a
single building over time this is kind
of your Classic Time series uh usage
pattern nothing special here
but the other one that we have that's a
little more tricky to handle is that
it's also important for us to be able to
retrieve data for an entire geographic
region for a single instant in time
this ends up being really important for
things like power flow simulation where
you need to know the energy load on an
entire circuit in order to run like
solve electrical engineering equations
and figure out what kind of what
equipment might have been overloaded at
that particular time so
we want to make sure we can serve this
use case as well with our time series
storage
and then we also have the batch
processing workflow which is what I've
been describing here and some of the big
uh needs here are making sure that you
can read and write large amounts of data
in bulk
and so ideally we'd end up with a way of
storing all our time series data that
would serve all these use cases at once
so our solution
was to use parquet files and break them
up into chunks that are partitioned by
both space and time
for the spatial partition we use census
block groups which are a geographic
division determined that's created by
the U.S Census Bureau and what's great
about these for our use case is they're
adjusted for the density of different
regions
so each census blog group has somewhere
between 500 and 3 000 people living in
it so
and you can see in this map of San
Francisco this shows what the census
block groups look like there and you can
see that it's adjusted for density with
some with the block groups being much
smaller and some of the more densely
populated regions
and for our time partition we use the
quarter of the year and these partitions
together mean that we can serve all the
the different use cases I described on
the previous slide and we end up with
chunks that are all around five
megabytes in size which is a pretty good
chunk size for making sure that we're
going to be able to retrieve small bits
of information efficiently for example
if we're just displaying it to an end
user on our platform we want that to be
low latency and we're also going to be
able we're also going to end up with not
too many small files so this ends up
being a good balance to serve all our
different use cases
so we turn this into a high partition
